CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be implicated in the adrenocortical zonation and in
CC       mechanisms for repressing the CYP11B1 gene expression in
CC       adrenocortical cells. This is a non catalytic peptidase C1 family
CC       protein. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12600995}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in kidney, heart and
CC       adrenocortical cells of adrenal glands. Moderately expressed in
CC       spleen and liver. Also found in prostate, seminal vesicle,
CC       epididymis and testis in male reproductive organs. In adrenal
CC       glands is found in the outer cortical regions corresponding to the
CC       zona glomerulosa (zG) and the undifferentiated cell zone (zU) (at
CC       protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11377975,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12600995}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Down-regulated in prostate after castration.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11377975}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C1 family.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU10089}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 SMB (somatomedin-B) domain. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-145 AND SER-239, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GTPase-activating protein (GAP) for ADP ribosylation
CC       factor 1 (ARF1). May regulate coatomer-mediated protein transport
CC       from the Golgi complex to the endoplasmic reticulum. Hydrolysis of
CC       ARF1-bound GTP may lead to dissociation of coatomer from Golgi-
CC       derived membranes to allow fusion with target membranes (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the coatomer complex. Interacts with the
CC       C-terminal appendage domain of COPG1 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=Also found on peripheral
CC       punctate structures likely to be endoplasmic reticulum-Golgi
CC       intermediate compartment. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q99K28-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q99K28-2; Sequence=VSP_023305;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in liver, heart and kidney.
CC       Low expression in skeletal muscle and spleen.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278321}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: High levels in mammary glands of virgin mice
CC       and in mammary glands of pregnant mice associated with extensive
CC       proliferation of ductal cells and lobulo-alveolar development.
CC       Expression declines at the beginning of lactation when the glands
CC       fully differentiate. No expression after day 2 of lactation until
CC       day 21. Expression may be controlled by ID1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278321}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 Arf-GAP domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00288}.

RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic

RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium-regulated, actin-modulating protein that binds
CC       to the plus (or barbed) ends of actin monomers or filaments,
CC       preventing monomer exchange (end-blocking or capping). It can
CC       promote the assembly of monomers into filaments (nucleation) as
CC       well as sever filaments already formed. Plays a role in
CC       ciliogenesis.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds to actin and to fibronectin. Identified in a
CC       complex composed of ACTA1, COBL, GSN AND TMSB4X (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with the inactive form of EIF2AK2/PKR. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22633459}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Secreted.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative initiation; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Secreted, Plasma;
CC         IsoId=P13020-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Cytoplasmic;
CC         IsoId=P13020-2; Sequence=VSP_018960;
CC         Note=Initiator Met-1 is removed or contains a N-acetylmethionine
CC         at position 1. {ECO:0000269|Ref.4};
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues in vitro. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the villin/gelsolin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 6 gelsolin-like repeats. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=20861308; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E10-04-0293;
RA   Ma X., Jana S.S., Conti M.A., Kawamoto S., Claycomb W.C.,
RA   Adelstein R.S.;
RT   "Ablation of nonmuscle myosin II-B and II-C reveals a role for
RT   nonmuscle myosin II in cardiac myocyte karyokinesis.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 21:3952-3962(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cellular myosin that appears to play a role in
CC       cytokinesis, cell shape, and specialized functions such as
CC       secretion and capping. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Myosin is a hexameric protein that consists of 2 heavy
CC       chain subunits (MHC), 2 alkali light chain subunits (MLC) and 2
CC       regulatory light chain subunits (MLC-2). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=NM II-C1;
CC         IsoId=Q6URW6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=Requires phosphorylation of the myosin regulatory light
CC         chain for activity.;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=NM II-C0;
CC         IsoId=Q6URW6-2; Sequence=VSP_014633;
CC         Note=Requires phosphorylation of the myosin regulatory light
CC         chain for activity.;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=NM II-C2;
CC         IsoId=Q6URW6-3; Sequence=VSP_014633, VSP_044759;
CC         Note=Constitutively active isoform which does not require
CC         phosphorylation of the regulatory myosin light chain for
CC         activity.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highest levels in lung, kidney, brain and
CC       colon, very low levels in liver and bladder and no expression in
CC       spleen or seminal vesicle (at protein level). Isoform 1 is
CC       expressed in liver, kidney and testis with low levels in skeletal
CC       muscle and heart. Isoform 1 and isoform 2 are expressed in brain
CC       and lung. Isoform 2 is the main isoform expressed in skeletal
CC       muscle and heart. Isoform 3 is limited to brain stem, cerebellum
CC       and spinal cord. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14594953,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19240025}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Widely expressed throughout the embryo at
CC       E11.5. Enhanced expression in the developing pituitary at E11.5.
CC       Expressed in developing lung from E13.5. At E16.5, confined to
CC       airway epithelial cells, developing sensory area of the cochlea
CC       and intestinal epithelial cells, particularly concentrated at
CC       their apical border. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14594953,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19240025, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20861308}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The rodlike tail sequence is highly repetitive, showing
CC       cycles of a 28-residue repeat pattern composed of 4 heptapeptides,
CC       characteristic for alpha-helical coiled coils. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Survival to adulthood with no obvious
CC       defects in brain structure, lung and heart development and no
CC       evidence for defective cell division. Deletion in animals
CC       expressing only 12% of wild-type amounts of Myh10 results in an
CC       increase in cardiac myocyte hypertrophy and interstitial fibrosis
CC       compared with the Myh10 hypomorphic animal.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20861308}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class myosin-kinesin ATPase
CC       superfamily. Myosin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 IQ domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00116}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 myosin motor domain. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GTP-binding protein. Can activate phospholipase D with
CC       very low efficiency. Important for normal function of the Golgi
CC       apparatus (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The GTP-bound form interacts with GOLGA1, GOLGA4 and
CC       RGPD8. The GTP-bound form directly interacts with ARFIP2; this
CC       interaction leads to an increase in the amount of bound GTP at
CC       steady state level. Binds to SCOC, preferentially in its GTP-bound
CC       form. May interact with UNC119 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the small GTPase superfamily. Arf family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [3]
RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT ALA-2, PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE
RP   SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-16, IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE
RP   SCALE ANALYSIS], AND CLEAVAGE OF INITIATOR METHIONINE [LARGE SCALE
RP   ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: eIF-2 functions in the early steps of protein synthesis
CC       by forming a ternary complex with GTP and initiator tRNA. This
CC       complex binds to a 40S ribosomal subunit, followed by mRNA binding
CC       to form a 43S preinitiation complex. Junction of the 60S ribosomal
CC       subunit to form the 80S initiation complex is preceded by
CC       hydrolysis of the GTP bound to eIF-2 and release of an eIF-2-GDP
CC       binary complex. In order for eIF-2 to recycle and catalyze another
CC       round of initiation, the GDP bound to eIF-2 must exchange with GTP
CC       by way of a reaction catalyzed by eIF-2B (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotrimer composed of an alpha, a beta and a gamma
CC       chain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class translation factor GTPase
CC       superfamily. Classic translation factor GTPase family. EIF2G

RA   Ehrmann I.E., Ellis P.S., Mazeyrat S., Duthie S., Brockdorff N.,

RC   TISSUE=Retina;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: eIF-2 functions in the early steps of protein synthesis
CC       by forming a ternary complex with GTP and initiator tRNA. This
CC       complex binds to a 40S ribosomal subunit, followed by mRNA binding
CC       to form a 43S preinitiation complex. Junction of the 60S ribosomal
CC       subunit to form the 80S initiation complex is preceded by
CC       hydrolysis of the GTP bound to eIF-2 and release of an eIF-2-GDP
CC       binary complex. In order for eIF-2 to recycle and catalyze another
CC       round of initiation, the GDP bound to eIF-2 must exchange with GTP
CC       by way of a reaction catalyzed by eIF-2B (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotrimer composed of an alpha, a beta and a gamma
CC       chain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class translation factor GTPase
CC       superfamily. Classic translation factor GTPase family. EIF2G
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01059}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 tr-type G (guanine nucleotide-binding)
CC       domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01059}.

RT   Pkd2.";
RL   Development 138:1131-1142(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a calcium permeable cation channel involved
CC       in fluid-flow mechanosensation by the primary cilium in renal
CC       epithelium. PKD1 and PKD2 may function through a common signaling
CC       pathway that is necessary for normal tubulogenesis. Acts as a
CC       regulator of cilium length, together with PKD1. The dynamic
CC       control of cilium length is essential in the regulation of
CC       mechanotransductive signaling. The cilium length response creates
CC       a negative feedback loop whereby fluid shear-mediated deflection
CC       of the primary cilium, which decreases intracellular cAMP, leads
CC       to cilium shortening and thus decreases flow-induced signaling.
CC       Also involved in left/right axis specification downstream of nodal
CC       flow: forms a complex with PKD2 in cilia to facilitate flow
CC       detection in left/right patterning. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12514735,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20096584, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms homooligomers. Isoform 1 interacts with PKD1 while
CC       isoform 3 does not. PKD1 requires the presence of PKD2 for stable
CC       expression. Interacts with CD2AP. Interacts with HAX1 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with NEK8. Part of a complex containing
CC       AKAP5, ADCY5, ADCY6 and PDE4C. Isoform 3 does not interact with
CC       PKD1. Interacts with PKD1L1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18235101, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21670265}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       E2JF22:Piezo1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-9823400, EBI-9837938;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell projection, cilium membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Endoplasmic reticulum {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=O35245-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=delta6;
CC         IsoId=O35245-2; Sequence=VSP_042485, VSP_042486;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=delta7;
CC         IsoId=O35245-3; Sequence=VSP_042487;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=delta9;
CC         IsoId=O35245-4; Sequence=VSP_042488, VSP_042489;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=delta12/13;
CC         IsoId=O35245-5; Sequence=VSP_042490;
CC         Note=Minor isoform.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in mesenchymally derived structures
CC       in the developing embryo at day 12.5. Isoform 1 is predominantly
CC       expressed in kidney at all developmental stages with high levels
CC       also detected in lung. Isoform 3 shows highest expression in brain
CC       with lower expression in kidney and lung, low levels in thymus and
CC       is hardly detectable in liver. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16192288,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21307093, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9716661}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain binds calcium and
CC       undergoes a calcium-induced conformation change. It is implicated
CC       in oligomerization and the interaction with PKD1 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polycystin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 EF-hand domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00448}.

CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + L-methionine + tRNA(Met) = AMP +

CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the multisynthetase complex which is
CC       comprised of a bifunctional glutamyl-prolyl-tRNA synthetase, the
CC       monospecific isoleucyl, leucyl, glutaminyl, methionyl, lysyl,
CC       arginyl, and aspartyl-tRNA synthetases as well as three auxiliary
CC       proteins, p18, p48 and p43. {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays a role in the TGF-beta/activin signaling pathway.
CC       It associates with inactive heteromeric TGF-beta and activin
CC       receptor complexes, mainly through the type II receptor, and is
CC       released upon activation of signaling. May recruit SMAD4 to the
CC       vicinity of the receptor complex and facilitate its interaction
CC       with receptor-regulated Smads, such as SMAD2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with TGFBR2 and ACVR2B; in the absence of
CC       ligand stimulation. Interacts with TGFBR1, ACVRL1, BMPR1A and
CC       ACVR1B; in the absence of ligand stimulation and to a less extent.
CC       Interacts with SMAD4; the interaction seems to be mutually
CC       exclusive with the interaction of SMAD4 and phosphorylated SMAD2.
CC       May interact with ALOX5 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Note=Colocalizes with TGF-beta
CC       receptors in the absence of signaling. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q3UR70-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q3UR70-2; Sequence=VSP_034944, VSP_034945;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAP1 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CHCR (clathrin heavy-chain) repeat.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01006}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CNH domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00795}.

RN   [17]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=23792957; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M113.482091;
RA   Bjorkblom B., Adilbayeva A., Maple-Grodem J., Piston D., Okvist M.,
RA   Xu X.M., Brede C., Larsen J.P., Moller S.G.;

RN   [18]
RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-148, SUCCINYLATION [LARGE
RP   SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-182, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY
RP   [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic
RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Protein deglycase that repairs methylglyoxal- and
CC       glyoxal-glycated amino acids and proteins, and releases repaired
CC       proteins and lactate or glycolate, respectively. Deglycates
CC       cysteines, arginines and lysines residues in proteins, and thus
CC       reactivates these proteins by reversing glycation by glyoxals.
CC       Acts on early glycation intermediates (hemithioacetals and
CC       aminocarbinols), preventing the formation of advanced glycation
CC       endproducts (AGE) (By similarity). Plays an important role in cell
CC       protection against oxidative stress and cell death acting as
CC       oxidative stress sensor and redox-sensitive chaperone and
CC       protease; functions probably related to its primary function
CC       (PubMed:15784737, PubMed:17015834, PubMed:20800516,
CC       PubMed:21068725). It is involved in neuroprotective mechanisms
CC       like the stabilization of NFE2L2 and PINK1 proteins, male
CC       fertility as a positive regulator of androgen signaling pathway
CC       and cell growth and transformation through, for instance, the
CC       modulation of NF-kappa-B signaling pathway (PubMed:17015834,
CC       PubMed:21097510). Its involvement in protein repair could explain
CC       other unrelated functions. Eliminates hydrogen peroxide and
CC       protects cells against hydrogen peroxide-induced cell death
CC       (PubMed:17766438). Required for correct mitochondrial morphology
CC       and function as well as for autophagy of dysfunctional
CC       mitochondria (PubMed:20186336). Plays a role in regulating
CC       expression or stability of the mitochondrial uncoupling proteins
CC       SLC25A14 and SLC25A27 in dopaminergic neurons of the substantia
CC       nigra pars compacta and attenuates the oxidative stress induced by
CC       calcium entry into the neurons via L-type channels during
CC       pacemaking (PubMed:21068725). Regulates astrocyte inflammatory
CC       responses, may modulate lipid rafts-dependent endocytosis in
CC       astrocytes and neuronal cells (PubMed:23847046, PubMed:19276172).
CC       Binds to a number of mRNAs containing multiple copies of GG or CC
CC       motifs and partially inhibits their translation but dissociates
CC       following oxidative stress (By similarity). Metal-binding protein
CC       able to bind copper as well as toxic mercury ions, enhances the
CC       cell protection mechanism against induced metal toxicity
CC       (PubMed:23792957). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15784737, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17015834,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17766438, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19276172,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20186336, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20800516,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21068725, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22523093,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23792957, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23847046}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Note=Does not require glutathione as a cofactor, however, glycated
CC       glutathione constitutes a PARK7 substrate.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Binds EFCAB6/DJBP and PIAS2. Part of a ternary
CC       complex containing PARK7, EFCAB6/DJBP and AR. Binds to HIPK1 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts (via N-terminus) with OTUD7B
CC       (PubMed:21097510). Interacts with BBS1, CLCF1 and MTERF
CC       (PubMed:21097510). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21097510}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23847046};
CC       Lipid-anchor {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23847046}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497}. Membrane raft
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23847046}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497}. Mitochondrion
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497}. Note=Under normal conditions,
CC       located predominantly in the cytoplasm and, to a lesser extent, in
CC       the nucleus and mitochondrion. Translocates to the mitochondrion
CC       and subsequently to the nucleus in response to oxidative stress
CC       and exerts an increased cytoprotective effect against oxidative
CC       damage (By similarity). Membrane raft localization in astrocytes
CC       and neuronal cells requires palmitoylation (PubMed:23847046).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23847046}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in erythroblasts and in mature red
CC       blood cells from peripheral blood (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20800516}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression increases during erythroid
CC       development (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20800516}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By hydrogen peroxide. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14749723}.
CC   -!- PTM: Sumoylated on Lys-130 by PIAS2 or PIAS4; which is essential
CC       for cell-growth promoting activity and transforming activity.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497}.
CC   -!- PTM: Undergoes cleavage of a C-terminal peptide and subsequent
CC       activation of protease activity in response to oxidative stress.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Increased sensitivity of embryonic cortical
CC       neurons to oxidative stress. Age-dependent increase in
CC       mitochondrial hydrogen peroxide production and reduced
CC       mitochondrial aconitase activity. Down-regulation of Slc25a14 and
CC       Slc25a27, compromised calcium-induced uncoupling and increased
CC       oxidation of mitochondrial matrix proteins specifically in the
CC       dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta.
CC       Reduced N2el2 protein expression. Impaired mitochondrial function
CC       and morphology with reduced autophagy leading to accumulation of
CC       defective mitochondria. Targeted knockouts in astrocytes exhibit
CC       augmented LPS-induced CRK/p38 phosphorylation and signaling, they
CC       don't stimulate TLR4 endocytosis upon LPS stimulation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15784737, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17015834,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17766438, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20186336,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21068725, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23847046}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C56 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Glyoxylase activity previously reported reflects in fact
CC       its deglycase activity (PubMed:22523093).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99497, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22523093}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of intercellular desmosome junctions. Involved
CC       in the interaction of plaque proteins and intermediate filaments
CC       mediating cell-cell adhesion.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Single-pass
CC       type I membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction, desmosome
CC       {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- DOMAIN: Three calcium ions are usually bound at the interface of
CC       each cadherin domain and rigidify the connections, imparting a
CC       strong curvature to the full-length ectodomain. {ECO:0000250}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.7 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH METHYL-GERFELIN,
RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, COFACTOR, ENZYME REGULATION, AND
RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=18695250; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0712239105;
RA   Kawatani M., Okumura H., Honda K., Kanoh N., Muroi M., Dohmae N.,
RA   Takami M., Kitagawa M., Futamura Y., Imoto M., Osada H.;
RT   "The identification of an osteoclastogenesis inhibitor through the
RT   inhibition of glyoxalase I.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105:11691-11696(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the conversion of hemimercaptal, formed from
CC       methylglyoxal and glutathione, to S-lactoylglutathione. Involved
CC       in the regulation of TNF-induced transcriptional activity of NF-
CC       kappa-B. Required for normal osteoclastogenesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (R)-S-lactoylglutathione = glutathione +
CC       methylglyoxal. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695250}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. In the homodimer, two zinc ions
CC       are bound between subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695250};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Subject to competitive inhibition by methyl-
CC       gerfelin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695250}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Secondary metabolite metabolism; methylglyoxal
CC       degradation; (R)-lactate from methylglyoxal: step 1/2.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18695250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glutathionylation at Cys-139 inhibits enzyme activity.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated at Thr-107 in the presence of CaMK2. However,
CC       this is a consensus site for phosphorylation by CK2 so
CC       phosphorylation may be mediated by CK2 rather than CaMK2.
CC       Phosphorylation is induced by TNF and suppresses the TNF-induced
CC       transcriptional activity of NF-kappa-B (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Exists in a nitric oxide (NO)-modified form. The exact nature
CC       of the modification is unknown, but it suppresses the TNF-induced
CC       transcriptional activity of NF-kappa-B (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Expressed at higher levels in CD-1 mice which have
CC       been bred for low-anxiety-related behavior than in those which
CC       have been bred for high-anxiety-related behavior.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glyoxalase I family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=FVB/N; TISSUE=Kidney;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the Mediator complex, a coactivator
CC       involved in the regulated transcription of nearly all RNA
CC       polymerase II-dependent genes. Mediator functions as a bridge to
CC       convey information from gene-specific regulatory proteins to the
CC       basal RNA polymerase II transcription machinery. Mediator is
CC       recruited to promoters by direct interactions with regulatory
CC       proteins and serves as a scaffold for the assembly of a functional
CC       preinitiation complex with RNA polymerase II and the general
CC       transcription factors (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Mediator complex, which is composed of
CC       MED1, MED4, MED6, MED7, MED8, MED9, MED10, MED11, MED12, MED13,
CC       MED13L, MED14, MED15, MED16, MED17, MED18, MED19, MED20, MED21,
CC       MED22, MED23, MED24, MED25, MED26, MED27, MED29, MED30, MED31,
CC       CCNC, CDK8 and CDC2L6/CDK11. The MED12, MED13, CCNC and CDK8
CC       subunits form a distinct module termed the CDK8 module. Mediator
CC       containing the CDK8 module is less active than Mediator lacking
CC       this module in supporting transcriptional activation. Individual
CC       preparations of the Mediator complex lacking one or more distinct
CC       subunits have been variously termed ARC, CRSP, DRIP, PC2, SMCC and
CC       TRAP (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9NVC6:MED17 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6260909, EBI-394562;
CC       Q15528:MED22 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6260909, EBI-394687;
CC       Q9H204:MED28 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6260909, EBI-514199;
CC       Q9NX70:MED29 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6260909, EBI-394656;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Mediator complex subunit 11 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [7]
RP   OXIDATION AT MET-44 AND MET-47, AND DEOXIDATION AT MET-44 AND MET-47.
RX   PubMed=23911929; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.019;
RA   Lee B.C., Peterfi Z., Hoffmann F.W., Moore R.E., Kaya A., Avanesov A.,
RA   Tarrago L., Zhou Y., Weerapana E., Fomenko D.E., Hoffmann P.R.,
RA   Gladyshev V.N.;
RT   "MsrB1 and MICALs regulate actin assembly and macrophage function via
RT   reversible stereoselective methionine oxidation.";
RL   Mol. Cell 51:397-404(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Actins are highly conserved proteins that are involved
CC       in various types of cell motility and are ubiquitously expressed
CC       in all eukaryotic cells.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Polymerization of globular actin (G-actin) leads to a
CC       structural filament (F-actin) in the form of a two-stranded helix.
CC       Each actin can bind to 4 others.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q08460:Kcnma1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-351301, EBI-1633915;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- PTM: Oxidation of Met-44 and Met-47 by MICALs (MICAL1, MICAL2 or
CC       MICAL3) to form methionine sulfoxide promotes actin filament
CC       depolymerization. MICAL1 and MICAL2 produce the (R)-S-oxide form.
CC       The (R)-S-oxide form is reverted by MSRB1 and MSRB2, which promote
CC       actin repolymerization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23911929}.
CC   -!- PTM: Monomethylation at Lys-84 (K84me1) regulates actin-myosin
CC       interaction and actomyosin-dependent processes. Demethylation by
CC       ALKBH4 is required for maintaining actomyosin dynamics supporting
CC       normal cleavage furrow ingression during cytokinesis and cell
CC       migration (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In vertebrates 3 main groups of actin isoforms,
CC       alpha, beta and gamma have been identified. The alpha actins are
CC       found in muscle tissues and are a major constituent of the
CC       contractile apparatus. The beta and gamma actins coexist in most
CC       cell types as components of the cytoskeleton and as mediators of
CC       internal cell motility.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the actin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RN   [14]
RP   INTERACTION WITH CAPN6.
RX   PubMed=21406564; DOI=10.1242/jcs.072561;
RA   Tonami K., Kurihara Y., Arima S., Nishiyama K., Uchijima Y., Asano T.,
RA   Sorimachi H., Kurihara H.;
RT   "Calpain-6, a microtubule-stabilizing protein, regulates Rac1 activity
RT   and cell motility through interaction with GEF-H1.";
RL   J. Cell Sci. 124:1214-1223(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Activates Rho-GTPases by promoting the exchange of GDP
CC       for GTP. May be involved in epithelial barrier permeability, cell
CC       motility and polarization, dendritic spine morphology, antigen
CC       presentation, leukemic cell differentiation, cell cycle
CC       regulation, innate immune response, and cancer. Binds Rac-GTPases,
CC       but does not seem to promote nucleotide exchange activity toward
CC       Rac-GTPases. May stimulate instead the cortical activity of Rac.
CC       Inactive toward CDC42, TC10, or Ras-GTPases. Forms an
CC       intracellular sensing system along with NOD1 for the detection of
CC       microbial effectors during cell invasion by pathogens. Involved in
CC       innate immune signaling transduction pathway promoting cytokine
CC       IL6/interleukin-6 and TNF-alpha secretion in macrophage upon
CC       stimulation by bacterial peptidoglycans; acts as a signaling
CC       intermediate between NOD2 receptor and RIPK2 kinase. Contributes
CC       to the tyrosine phosphorylation of RIPK2 through Src tyrosine
CC       kinase leading to NF-kappaB activation by NOD2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Found in a complex composed at least of ARHGEF2, NOD2 and
CC       RIPK2. Interacts with RIPK2; the interaction mediates tyrosine
CC       phosphorylation of RIPK2 by Src kinase CSK. Interacts with RIPK1
CC       and RIPK3. Interacts with YWHAZ/14-3-3 zeta; when phosphorylated
CC       at Ser-885. Interacts with the kinases PAK4, AURKA and MAPK1.
CC       Interacts with RHOA and RAC1. Interacts with NOD1 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts (via the N- terminal zinc finger) with CAPN6 (via domain
CC       II). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21406564}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q61097:Ksr1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-772191, EBI-1536336;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction,
CC       tight junction {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12604587}. Golgi apparatus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, spindle {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Cytoplasmic vesicle {ECO:0000250}. Note=Localizes to the tips of
CC       cortical microtubules of the mitotic spindle during cell division,
CC       and is further released upon microtubule depolymerization.
CC       Colocalized with NOD2 and RIPK2 in vesicles and with the
CC       cytoskeleton (By similarity). Associated with apical intercellular
CC       junctions in the trophectoderm of the blastocyst. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-2; Sequence=VSP_022641;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-3; Sequence=VSP_022640, VSP_022642, VSP_022643;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-4; Sequence=VSP_034962;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q60875-5; Sequence=VSP_034962, VSP_034963;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Ubiquitous, with the exception of liver
CC       tissue. Levels are high in hemopoietic tissues (thymus, spleen,
CC       bone marrow) as well as in kidney and lung.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The DH (DBL-homology) domain promotes tyrosine
CC       phosphorylation of RIPK2 (By similarity). The DH (DBL-homology)
CC       domain interacts with and promotes loading of GTP on RhoA.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PH (pleckstrin-homology) domain is involved in
CC       microtubule binding and targeting to tight junctions.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Ser-885 by PAK1 induces binding to protein
CC       YWHAZ, promoting its relocation to microtubules and the inhibition
CC       of its activity. Phosphorylated by AURKA and CDK1 during mitosis,
CC       which negatively regulates its activity. Phosphorylation by MAPK1
CC       or MAPK3 increases nucleotide exchange activity. Phosphorylation
CC       by PAK4 releases GEF-H1 from the microtubules. Phosphorylated on
CC       serine, threonine and tyrosine residues in a RIPK2-dependent
CC       manner (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 DH (DBL-homology) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00062}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PH domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00145}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 phorbol-ester/DAG-type zinc finger.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00226}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=BAC41438.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally shortened.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May play a role in vesicle-mediated protein trafficking
CC       to lysosomal compartments and in membrane docking/fusion reactions
CC       of late endosomes/lysosomes. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RAB11A and VIPAS39.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20190753}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P62492:Rab11a; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2656383, EBI-770256;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Late endosome membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Lysosome membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Cytoplasmic, peripheral membrane protein associated with late
CC       endosomes/lysosomes. Colocalizes in clusters with VIPAS39 at
CC       cytoplasmic organelles (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Vps33b-deficient inner medullary collecting duct
CC       cells display abnormal expression of membrane proteins such as
CC       Ceacam5, structural and functional tight junction defects and
CC       reduced E-cadherin expression.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the STXBP/unc-18/SEC1 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH APAF1.
RX   PubMed=15271982; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M402902200;
RA   Sakai T., Liu L., Teng X., Mukai-Sakai R., Shimada H., Kaji R.,

RP   FUNCTION, INTERACTION WITH LGALS3, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=14961764; DOI=10.1042/BJ20031300;
RA   Liu L., Sakai T., Sano N., Fukui K.;
RT   "Nucling mediates apoptosis by inhibiting expression of galectin-3
RT   through interference with nuclear factor kappaB signalling.";

RN   [7]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-280, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19144319; DOI=10.1016/j.immuni.2008.11.006;
RA   Trost M., English L., Lemieux S., Courcelles M., Desjardins M.,
RA   Thibault P.;
RT   "The phagosomal proteome in interferon-gamma-activated macrophages.";
RL   Immunity 30:143-154(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulates APAF1 expression and plays an important role
CC       in the regulation of stress-induced apoptosis. Promotes apoptosis
CC       by regulating three pathways, apoptosome up-regulation,
CC       LGALS3/galectin-3 down-regulation and NF-kappa-B inactivation.
CC       Regulates the redistribution of APAF1 into the nucleus after
CC       proapoptotic stress. Down-regulates the expression of LGALS3 by
CC       inhibiting NFKB1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14961764,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15271982}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Modulates isoactin dynamics to regulate the
CC       morphological alterations required for cell growth and motility.
CC       Interaction with ARF6 may modulate cell shape and motility after
CC       injury (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the apoptosome complex, composed of APAF1,
CC       pro-caspase-9 and UACA. In the complex, it probably interacts
CC       directly with APAF1. Interacts with LGALS3, ARF6 and ACTB.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14961764, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15271982}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761289}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761289}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761289}. Note=Expressed diffusely in
CC       cytoplasm.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8CGB3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8CGB3-2; Sequence=VSP_017874;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8CGB3-3; Sequence=VSP_017875;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in heart, liver, kidney and
CC       testis. Weakly expressed in lung and skeletal muscle. Not
CC       expressed in brain and spleen. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761289}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: First detected at the E9.5 stage in heart at
CC       the edge of both sides of the common ventricular chamber and is
CC       then progressively increased and restricted to the myocardial wall
CC       of left common ventricular chamber of heart.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761289}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated during cardiomyogenic differentiation. By
CC       apoptotic stress in a dose-dependent manner.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761289}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice show a high incidence of inflammatory
CC       lesions in preputial glands. Cells around the lesions showed
CC       resistance to apoptosis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14961764}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 6 ANK repeats. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00023}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6 {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AAH58242.1}, and
RC   FVB/N {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AAH23462.1};
RC   TISSUE=Kidney {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AAH23462.1}, and
RC   Olfactory epithelium {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AAH58242.1};
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Oxygenase that can act as both a histone lysine
CC       demethylase and a ribosomal histidine hydroxylase. Is involved in
CC       the demethylation of trimethylated 'Lys-9' on histone H3
CC       (H3K9me3), leading to an increase in ribosomal RNA expression.
CC       Also catalyzes the hydroxylation of 60S ribosomal protein L27a on
CC       'His-39' (By similarity). May play an important role in cell
CC       growth and survival. May be involved in ribosome biogenesis, most
CC       likely during the assembly process of pre-ribosomal particles.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16533354}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: L-histidine-[60S ribosomal protein L27a] + 2-
CC       oxoglutarate + O(2) = (3S)-3-hydroxy-L-histidine-[60S ribosomal
CC       protein L27a] + succinate + CO(2).
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Fe(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29033; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 Fe(2+) ion per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16533354}.
CC       Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16533354}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in testis. Expressed
CC       at high levels in spleen, thymus, and colon, but barely detectable
CC       in brain, skeletal muscle, and seminal vesicle (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16533354}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: In testis, expressed in the nuclei of
CC       spermatogonia at all stages of the seminiferous epithelial cycle,
CC       and in meiotic prophase cells such as preleptotene, leptotene and
CC       zygotene, and weakly in early pachytene spermatocytes, but is
CC       absent in late pachytene spermatocytes, spermatids and mature
CC       sperm (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16533354}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated in experimentally-induced cryptorchid
CC       testis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16533354}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MINA53/NO66 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 JmjC domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00538}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of cohesin complex, a complex required for the
CC       cohesion of sister chromatids after DNA replication. The cohesin
CC       complex apparently forms a large proteinaceous ring within which
CC       sister chromatids can be trapped. At anaphase, the complex is
CC       cleaved and dissociates from chromatin, allowing sister chromatids
CC       to segregate. The cohesin complex may also play a role in spindle
CC       pole assembly during mitosis (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts directly with RAD21 in cohesin complex. Cohesin
CC       complexes are composed of a heterodimer between a SMC1 protein
CC       (SMC1A or SMC1B) and SMC3, which are attached via their hinge
CC       domain, and RAD21 which link them at their heads, and one STAG
CC       protein (STAG1, STAG2 or STAG3). In cohesin complexes, STAG2 is
CC       mutually exclusive with STAG1 and STAG3 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Chromosome {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Chromosome, centromere {ECO:0000250}. Note=Associates with
CC       chromatin. Before prophase it is scattered along chromosome arms.
CC       During prophase, most of cohesin complexes dissociate from
CC       chromatin probably because of phosphorylation by PLK1, except at
CC       centromeres, where cohesin complexes remain. At anaphase, the
CC       RAD21 subunit of cohesin is cleaved, leading to the dissociation
CC       of the complex from chromosomes, allowing chromosome separation.
CC       In germ cells, cohesin complex dissociates from chromatin at
CC       prophase I, and may be replaced by a meiosis-specific cohesin
CC       complex (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by PLK1. The large dissociation of cohesin
CC       from chromosome arms during prophase is partly due to its
CC       phosphorylation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SCC3 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 SCD (stromalin conservative) domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00750}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=BC066041; Type=Frameshift; Positions=54; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=BC066041; Type=Frameshift; Positions=53; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAA05638.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=22; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Binds RNA. {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12837692}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12837692}. Note=Localized in both
CC       nucleus and cytoplasm in most neurons. In the cortex, distributed
CC       in a diffuse way in the nucleus and in the cytoplasm. Localized in
CC       the cytoplasm in neurons of the dentate gyrus in the olfactive
CC       bulb, in the ependymal epithelium and in the granular layer of the
CC       cerebellum. In Purkinje cells, distributed in both cell
CC       compartments and in nuclear dots adjacent to the nucleolus.

RP   1090-1106; 1111-1137 AND 1159-1165, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, DNA-BINDING,

RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY, IDENTIFICATION IN THE
RP   CST COMPLEX, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=19854130; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2009.08.009;
RA   Miyake Y., Nakamura M., Nabetani A., Shimamura S., Tamura M.,
RA   Yonehara S., Saito M., Ishikawa F.;
RT   "RPA-like mammalian Ctc1-Stn1-Ten1 complex binds to single-stranded
RT   DNA and protects telomeres independently of the Pot1 pathway.";
RL   Mol. Cell 36:193-206(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the CST complex, a complex that binds to
CC       single-stranded DNA and is required to protect telomeres from DNA
CC       degradation. The CST complex binds single-stranded DNA with high
CC       affinity in a sequence-independent manner, while isolated subunits
CC       bind DNA with low affinity by themselves. In addition to telomere
CC       protection, the CST complex has probably a more general role in
CC       DNA metabolism at non-telomeric sites.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19854130}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the CST complex, composed of TEN1, CTC1 and
CC       STN1/OBFC1. Interacts with STN1/OBFC1; the interaction is direct.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19119139, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19854130}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Chromosome, telomere. Note=A
CC       transmembrane region is predicted by sequence analysis tools
CC       (ESKW, MEMSAT and Phobius); however, given the telomeric
CC       localization of the protein, the relevance of the transmembrane
CC       region is unsure in vivo.

CC         IsoId=Q5SUQ9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q5SUQ9-2; Sequence=VSP_025355;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;

RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-486, AND IDENTIFICATION BY
RP   MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic
RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Myosins are actin-based motor molecules with ATPase
CC       activity. Unconventional myosins serve in intracellular movements.
CC       Their highly divergent tails bind to membranous compartments,
CC       which then are moved relative to actin filaments. Involved in
CC       glucose transporter recycling in response to insulin by regulating
CC       movement of intracellular GLUT4-containing vesicles to the plasma
CC       membrane. Component of the hair cell's (the sensory cells of the
CC       inner ear) adaptation-motor complex. Acts as a mediator of
CC       adaptation of mechanoelectrical transduction in stereocilia of
CC       vestibular hair cells. Binds phosphoinositides and links the actin
CC       cytoskeleton to cellular membranes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16971510}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform 3 is involved in regulation of transcription.
CC       Associated with transcriptional active ribosomal genes. Appears to
CC       cooperate with the WICH chromatin-remodeling complex to facilitate
CC       transcription. Necessary for the formation of the first
CC       phosphodiester bond during transcription initiation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via its IQ motifs) with CALM; this precludes
CC       interaction with YWHAB. Interacts with YWHAB; this precludes
CC       interaction with CALM. Interacts with RPS6 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with actin filaments. Interacts (via its IQ motifs) with
CC       CABP1 and CIB1; the interaction with CABP1 and CIB1 is calcium-
CC       dependent. Interacts (via tail domain) with PLEKHB1 (via PH
CC       domain); the interaction is not affected by the presence or
CC       absence of calcium and CALM. Interacts with POLR1A and POLR2A.
CC       Component of the B-WICH complex, at least composed of
CC       SMARCA5/SNF2H, BAZ1B/WSTF, SF3B1, DEK, MYO1C, ERCC6, MYBBP1A and
CC       DDX21. Interacts with GLUT4. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11030652, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15976448,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16514417, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16960872,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17994197, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22918957}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9QYE9-1:Plekhb1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-777558, EBI-1127141;
CC       Q9QYE9-2:Plekhb1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-777558, EBI-1127145;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Cell membrane; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Cell projection, stereocilium
CC       membrane. Cytoplasmic vesicle. Cell projection, ruffle.
CC       Note=Colocalizes with CABP1 and CIB1 at cell margin, membrane
CC       ruffles and punctate regions on the cell membrane. Colocalizes in
CC       adipocytes with GLUT4 at actin-based membranes. Colocalizes with
CC       GLUT4 at insulin-induced ruffles at the cell membrane. Localizes
CC       transiently at cell membrane to region known to be enriched in
CC       PIP2. Activation of phospholipase C results in its redistribution
CC       to the cytoplasm.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 3: Nucleus, nucleolus. Nucleus,
CC       nucleoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus, nuclear pore complex
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=In the nucleolus, is localized predominantly
CC       in dense fibrillar component (DFC) and in granular component (GC).
CC       Accumulates strongly in DFC and GC during activation of
CC       transcription. Colocalizes with transcription sites. Colocalizes
CC       in the granular cortex at the periphery of the nucleolus with
CC       RPS6. Colocalizes in nucleoplasm with RPS6 and actin that are in
CC       contact with RNP particles. Colocalizes with RPS6 at the nuclear
CC       pore level (By similarity). Colocalizes with RNA polymerase II in
CC       the nucleus. Colocalizes with RNA polymerase I in nucleoli.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9WTI7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=Gene prediction based on EST data.;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q9WTI7-2; Sequence=VSP_036863;
CC         Note=Contains a N-acetylmethionine at position 1. {ECO:0000250};
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=Nuclear myosin 1, NM1;
CC         IsoId=Q9WTI7-3; Sequence=VSP_036864;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=B;
CC         IsoId=Q9WTI7-4; Sequence=VSP_003350;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. May be due to a
CC         frameshift.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform 3 is expressed in small intestine,
CC       pancreas, brain, kidney, skin, heart muscle, testis, striated
CC       muscle, spleen, liver and lung (at protein level). Expressed in
CC       brain, testis, adrenal glands, thymus, spleen, kidney, lung,
CC       heart, cochlea and vestibule. Expressed in sensory hair cells of
CC       the inner ear. Expressed in adipocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12490950, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16102537,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16957816, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9119401}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by serum. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16957816}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Binds directly to large unilamellar vesicles (LUVs)
CC       containing phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) or
CC       inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (InsP3). The PIP2-binding site
CC       corresponds to the myosin tail domain (PH-like) present in its
CC       tail domain. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16971510}.
CC   -!- PTM: Isoform 2 contains a N-acetylmethionine at position 1.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class myosin-kinesin ATPase
CC       superfamily. Myosin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 IQ domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00116}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 myosin motor domain. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 myosin tail domain. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Represents an unconventional myosin. This protein should
CC       not be confused with the conventional myosin-1 (MYH1).
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the nuclear pore complex, a complex
CC       required for the trafficking across the nuclear membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the p62 complex, a complex at least composed
CC       of NUP62, NUP54, and NUPL1. Interacts with NUTF2. Interacts with
CC       SRP1-alpha and Importin p97 proteins when they are together, but
CC       not with SRP1-alpha protein alone (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P63085:Mapk1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-646962, EBI-397697;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nuclear pore complex {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Nucleus membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Nucleoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=Biased towards cytoplasmic
CC       side. Central region of the nuclear pore complex, within the
CC       transporter (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.

RP   PROTEIN SEQUENCE OF 368-387, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   STRAIN=OF1; TISSUE=Hippocampus;
RA   Lubec G., Sunyer B., Chen W.-Q.;
RL   Submitted (JAN-2009) to UniProtKB.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Blocks interferon-dependent interphase and stimulates
CC       DNA synthesis in cells. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer of two type I and two type II keratins.
CC       Interacts with eukaryotic translation initiator factor 3 (eIF3)
CC       subunit EIF3S10. Interacts with GPER1 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in most simple epithelia tested
CC       including liver, lactating mammary gland, lung, kidney, stomach,
CC       duodenum, colon, oviduct, uterus, pancreas, epididymis, prostate,
CC       preputial gland and mesothelium, and in most stratified epithelia
CC       tested including dorsal skin, paw/toe, tail, tongue, cervix,
CC       forestomach, and bladder. Also expressed in Henle layer of the
CC       inner root sheath of whisker follicle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12359226}.
CC   -!- PTM: Arg-15 is dimethylated, probably to asymmetric
CC       dimethylarginine. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P08729}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are two types of cytoskeletal and
CC       microfibrillar keratin: I (acidic; 40-55 kDa) and II (neutral to
CC       basic; 56-70 kDa). {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the intermediate filament family.
CC       {ECO:0000255}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 1-171.
RG   RIKEN structural genomics initiative (RSGI);
RT   "Solution structure of the first and second DSRM domain in interferon-
RT   induced, double-stranded RNA-activated protein kinase.";
RL   Submitted (NOV-2005) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: IFN-induced dsRNA-dependent serine/threonine-protein
CC       kinase which plays a key role in the innate immune response to
CC       viral infection and is also involved in the regulation of signal
CC       transduction, apoptosis, cell proliferation and differentiation.
CC       Exerts its antiviral activity on a wide range of DNA and RNA
CC       viruses including west nile virus (WNV), sindbis virus (SV), foot-
CC       and-mouth virus (FMDV), semliki Forest virus (SFV) and lymphocytic
CC       choriomeningitis virus (LCMV). Inhibits viral replication via
CC       phosphorylation of the alpha subunit of eukaryotic initiation
CC       factor 2 (EIF2S1), this phosphorylation impairs the recycling of
CC       EIF2S1 between successive rounds of initiation leading to
CC       inhibition of translation which eventually results in shutdown of
CC       cellular and viral protein synthesis. Also phosphorylates other
CC       substrates including p53/TP53, PPP2R5A, DHX9, ILF3 and IRS1. In
CC       addition to serine/threonine-protein kinase activity, also has
CC       tyrosine-protein kinase activity and phosphorylates CDK1 at 'Tyr-
CC       4' upon DNA damage, facilitating its ubiquitination and
CC       proteosomal degradation. Either as an adapter protein and/or via
CC       its kinase activity, can regulate various signaling pathways (p38
CC       MAP kinase, NF-kappa-B and insulin signaling pathways) and
CC       transcription factors (JUN, STAT1, STAT3, IRF1, ATF3) involved in
CC       the expression of genes encoding proinflammatory cytokines and
CC       IFNs. Activates the NF-kappa-B pathway via interaction with IKBKB
CC       and TRAF family of proteins and activates the p38 MAP kinase
CC       pathway via interaction with MAP2K6. Can act as both a positive
CC       and negative regulator of the insulin signaling pathway (ISP).
CC       Negatively regulates ISP by inducing the inhibitory
CC       phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS1) at 'Ser-
CC       312' and positively regulates ISP via phosphorylation of PPP2R5A
CC       which activates FOXO1, which in turn up-regulates the expression
CC       of insulin receptor substrate 2 (IRS2). Can regulate NLRP3
CC       inflammasome assembly and the activation of NLRP3, NLRP1, AIM2 and
CC       NLRC4 inflammasomes. Can trigger apoptosis via FADD-mediated
CC       activation of CASP8. Plays a role in the regulation of the
CC       cytoskeleton by binding to gelsolin (GSN), sequestering the
CC       protein in an inactive conformation away from actin. Regulates
CC       proliferation, differentiation and survival of hematopoietic
CC       stem/progenitor cells, induction of cytokines and chemokines and
CC       plays a role in cortex-dependent memory consolidation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19229320, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19264662,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20038207, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20478537,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20585572, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20631127,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21123651, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21994357,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22633459, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22801494,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22948222, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23392680,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23401008, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23403623}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a [protein]-L-tyrosine = ADP + a
CC       [protein]-L-tyrosine phosphate. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU10027}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Initially produced in an inactive form and is
CC       activated by binding to viral dsRNA, which causes dimerization and
CC       autophosphorylation in the activation loop and stimulation of
CC       function. ISGylation can activate it in the absence of viral
CC       infection. Can also be activated by heparin, proinflammatory
CC       stimuli, growth factors, cytokines, oxidative stress and the
CC       cellular protein PRKRA. Activity is markedly stimulated by
CC       manganese ions. Activation is blocked by the cellular proteins
CC       TARBP2, DUS2L, NPM1, NCK1 and ADAR (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with DNAJC3 and STRBP (By
CC       similarity). Forms a complex with FANCA, FANCC, FANCG and HSP70
CC       (By similarity). Interacts with ADAR/ADAR1. The inactive form
CC       interacts with NCK1. Interacts (via the kinase catalytic domain)
CC       with STAT3 (via SH2 domain), TRAF2 (C-terminus), TRAF5 (C-
CC       terminus) and TRAF6 (C-terminus). Interacts with MAP2K6, TARBP2,
CC       NLRP1, NLRC4 and AIM2. Interacts (via DRBM 1 domain) with DUS2L
CC       (via DRBM domain) (By similarity). Interacts with DHX9 (via N-
CC       terminus) and this interaction is dependent upon activation of the
CC       kinase. The inactive form interacts with GSN. Interacts with
CC       IKBKB/IKKB, NPM1, NLRP3 and IRS1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10848580, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12882984,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17079286, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19229320,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22633459, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22801494,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22948222}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P35569:Irs1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2603444, EBI-400825;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, perinuclear region {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in heart, lung, brain, kidney,
CC       testes, thymus and bone marrow.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By type I interferons. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Autophosphorylated on several Ser, Thr and Tyr residues.
CC       Autophosphorylation of Thr-414 is dependent on Thr-409 and is
CC       stimulated by dsRNA binding and dimerization. Autophosphorylation
CC       apparently leads to the activation of the kinase. Tyrosine
CC       autophosphorylation is essential for efficient dsRNA-binding,
CC       dimerization, and kinase activation (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice have significantly elevated numbers of
CC       bone marrow derived hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs)
CC       and which are more actively proliferating and resistant to stress.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23403623}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. Ser/Thr
CC       protein kinase family. GCN2 subfamily. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00159}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 DRBM (double-stranded RNA-binding) domains.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00266}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 protein kinase domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00159}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RL   J. Cell Biol. 159:579-588(2002).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORM 2).
RC   TISSUE=Testis;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Key regulator of the exon junction complex (EJC), a
CC       multiprotein complex that associates immediately upstream of the
CC       exon-exon junction on mRNAs and serves as a positional landmarks
CC       for the intron exon structure of genes and directs post-
CC       transcriptional processes in the cytoplasm such as mRNA export,
CC       nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) or translation. Acts as a EJC
CC       disassembly factor, allowing translation-dependent EJC removal and
CC       recycling by disrupting mature EJC from spliced mRNAs. Its
CC       association with the 40S ribosomal subunit probably prevents a
CC       translation-independent disassembly of the EJC from spliced mRNAs,
CC       by restricting its activity to mRNAs that have been translated.
CC       Interferes with NMD and enhances translation of spliced mRNAs,
CC       probably by antagonizing EJC functions (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via N-terminus) with MAGOH and RBM8A; the
CC       interaction is direct. Associates (eIF2A-like region) with the 40S
CC       ribosomal subunit and the 48S preinitiation complex (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus, nucleolus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus, nucleoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Note=Shuttles
CC       between the nucleus and the cytoplasm. Nuclear export is mediated
CC       by XPO1/CRM1 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8CHP5-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8CHP5-2; Sequence=VSP_025431;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The eIF2A-like region shares sequence similarity with
CC       eIF2A and mediates the interaction with the 40S ribosomal subunit
CC       and the 48S preinitiation complex. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the wibg family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   ACETYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-74, AND IDENTIFICATION BY

RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;
RX   PubMed=23806337; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2013.06.001;
RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Organizes filamentous actin into bundles with a minimum
CC       of 4.1:1 actin/fascin ratio. Plays a role in the organization of
CC       actin filament bundles and the formation of microspikes, membrane
CC       ruffles, and stress fibers. Important for the formation of a
CC       diverse set of cell protrusions, such as filopodia, and for cell
CC       motility and migration (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with beta-catenin. Interacts with PLXNB3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21706053}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9QY40:Plxnb3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2308857, EBI-6271317;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton {ECO:0000250}. Cell
CC       projection, filopodium {ECO:0000250}. Cell projection,
CC       invadopodium {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasm, cytosol {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=In glioma cells, partially colocalizes with F-actin stress
CC       fibers in the cytosol. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Most abundant in brain. Found in other tissues
CC       including uterus, small intestine and spleen.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Composed of four beta-trefoil domains. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation on Ser-39 inhibits the actin-binding ability
CC       of fascin. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the fascin family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=18625303; DOI=10.1016/j.cellsig.2008.06.011;
RA   Zhao B., Wong A.Y.C., Murshid A., Bowie D., Presley J.F.,

RT   "Identification of a novel di-leucine motif mediating K(+)/Cl(-)
RT   cotransporter KCC2 constitutive endocytosis.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the adaptor protein complex 2 (AP-2).
CC       Adaptor protein complexes function in protein transport via
CC       transport vesicles in different membrane traffic pathways. Adaptor
CC       protein complexes are vesicle coat components and appear to be
CC       involved in cargo selection and vesicle formation. AP-2 is
CC       involved in clathrin-dependent endocytosis in which cargo proteins
CC       are incorporated into vesicles surrounded by clathrin (clathrin-
CC       coated vesicles, CCVs) which are destined for fusion with the
CC       early endosome. The clathrin lattice serves as a mechanical
CC       scaffold but is itself unable to bind directly to membrane
CC       components. Clathrin-associated adaptor protein (AP) complexes
CC       which can bind directly to both the clathrin lattice and to the
CC       lipid and protein components of membranes are considered to be the
CC       major clathrin adaptors contributing the CCV formation. AP-2 also
CC       serves as a cargo receptor to selectively sort the membrane
CC       proteins involved in receptor-mediated endocytosis. AP-2 seems to
CC       play a role in the recycling of synaptic vesicle membranes from
CC       the presynaptic surface. AP-2 recognizes Y-X-X-[FILMV] (Y-X-X-Phi)
CC       and [ED]-X-X-X-L-[LI] endocytosis signal motifs within the
CC       cytosolic tails of transmembrane cargo molecules. AP-2 may also
CC       play a role in maintaining normal post-endocytic trafficking
CC       through the ARF6-regulated, non-clathrin pathway. The AP-2 alpha
CC       subunit binds polyphosphoinositide-containing lipids, positioning
CC       AP-2 on the membrane. The AP-2 alpha subunit acts via its C-
CC       terminal appendage domain as a scaffolding platform for endocytic
CC       accessory proteins. The AP-2 alpha and AP-2 sigma subunits are
CC       thought to contribute to the recognition of the [ED]-X-X-X-L-[LI]
CC       motif (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Adaptor protein complex 2 (AP-2) is a heterotetramer
CC       composed of two large adaptins (alpha-type subunit AP2A1 or AP2A2
CC       and beta-type subunit AP2B1), a medium adaptin (mu-type subunit
CC       AP2M1) and a small adaptin (sigma-type subunit AP2S1). Interacts
CC       with HIP1 and RAB11FIP2 (By similarity). Interacts with SLC12A5.
CC       Interacts with clathrin. Interacts with SLC12A5. Interacts with
CC       clathrin. Interacts with SGIP1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17626015, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18625303,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7559550}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q01097:Grin2b; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-775189, EBI-400125;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}. Membrane,
CC       coated pit {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=AP-2 appears
CC       to be excluded from internalizing CCVs and to disengage from sites
CC       of endocytosis seconds before internalization of the nascent CCV.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=A;
CC         IsoId=P17426-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B;
CC         IsoId=P17426-2; Sequence=VSP_000162;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform A is expressed only in neuronal tissue
CC       and skeletal muscle. Isoform B is widely expressed.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the adaptor complexes large subunit family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: mRNA-binding protein involved in translation elongation.
CC       Has an important function at the level of mRNA turnover, probably
CC       acting downstream of decapping. Involved in actin dynamics and
CC       cell cycle progression, mRNA decay and probably in a pathway
CC       involved in stress response and maintenance of cell wall
CC       integrity. Functions as a regulator of apoptosis. Mediates effects
CC       of polyamines on neuronal process extension and survival. May play
CC       an important role in brain development and function, and in
CC       skeletal muscle stem cell differentiation (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus, nuclear pore complex {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Hypusine modification promotes the nuclear export and
CC       cytoplasmic localization and there was a dynamic shift in the
CC       localization from predominantly cytoplasmic to primarily nuclear
CC       under apoptotic inducing conditions. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: eIF-5A seems to be the only eukaryotic protein to have a
CC       hypusine residue which is a post-translational modification of a
CC       lysine by the addition of a butylamino group (from spermidine).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eIF-5A family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Destroys superoxide anion radicals which are normally
CC       produced within the cells and which are toxic to biological
CC       systems.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 superoxide + 2 H(+) = O(2) + H(2)O(2).
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29035; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 Mn(2+) ion per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P54099:Polg; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1635071, EBI-863636;
CC       P02340:Tp53; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1635071, EBI-474016;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion matrix.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression is regulated by KRIT1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20668652}.
CC   -!- PTM: Nitrated under oxidative stress. Nitration coupled with
CC       oxidation inhibits the catalytic activity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Acetylation at Lys-122 decreases enzymatic activity.
CC       Deacetylated by SIRT3 upon exposure to ionizing radiations or
CC       after long fasting. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21172655}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the iron/manganese superoxide dismutase
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in transcriptional activation and repression of
CC       select genes by chromatin remodeling (alteration of DNA-nucleosome
CC       topology). Acts as a negative regulator of cell proliferation.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the SWI/SNF-B (PBAF) chromatin-remodeling
CC       complex, which contains at least SMARCA4/BRG1,
CC       SMARCB1/SNF5/INI1/BAF47, ACTL6A/BAF53A or ACTL6B/BAF53B,
CC       SMARCE1/BAF57, SMARCD1/BAF60A, SMARCD2/BAF60B, perhaps
CC       SMARCD3/BAF60C, SMARCC1/BAF155, SMARCC2/BAF170, PB1/BAF180,
CC       ARID2/BAF200, ARID1A/BAF250A or ARID1B/BAF250B and actin.
CC       Interacts with acetylated 'Lys-14' of histone H3 (H3K14ac), and
CC       may also interact with other acetylated or methylated Lys residues
CC       on histone H3 (By similarity). Interacts with PHF10/BAF45A.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17640523}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00267}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8BSQ9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8BSQ9-2; Sequence=VSP_035471;
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed ubiquitously throughout the
CC       developing spinal cord, brain and other embryonic tissues at
CC       E10.5-E16.5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17640523}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 BAH domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00370}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 6 bromo domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00035}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 HMG box DNA-binding domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00267}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May play a role in cell death control. Acts as a
CC       transcriptional repressor. Has been shown to repress transcription
CC       of SRF in vitro and so may play a role in heart development (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with XIAP. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18068114}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12107429,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18068114}. Note=Some staining in the cytosol;
CC       cytosolic localization is reduced in staurosporine-induced cell
CC       death.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytochrome c oxidase is the component of the respiratory
CC       chain that catalyzes the reduction of oxygen to water. Subunits 1-
CC       3 form the functional core of the enzyme complex. Subunit 2
CC       transfers the electrons from cytochrome c via its binuclear copper
CC       A center to the bimetallic center of the catalytic subunit 1.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Cu cation; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:23378;
CC       Note=Binds a copper A center.;

CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome c oxidase subunit 2 family.

RA   Brandt S., Ellwanger K., Beuter-Gunia C., Schuster M., Hausser A.,
