RP   THR-448 AND SER-450, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE
RP   SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=17242355; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609836104;
RA   Villen J., Beausoleil S.A., Gerber S.A., Gygi S.P.;
RT   "Large-scale phosphorylation analysis of mouse liver.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:1488-1493(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Serine/arginine-rich protein-specific kinase which
CC       specifically phosphorylates its substrates at serine residues
CC       located in regions rich in arginine/serine dipeptides, known as RS
CC       domains and is involved in the phosphorylation of SR splicing
CC       factors and the regulation of splicing. Plays a central role in
CC       the regulatory network for splicing, controlling the intranuclear
CC       distribution of splicing factors in interphase cells and the
CC       reorganization of nuclear speckles during mitosis. Can influence
CC       additional steps of mRNA maturation, as well as other cellular
CC       activities, such as chromatin reorganization in somatic and sperm
CC       cells and cell cycle progression. Phosphorylates SFRS2, ZRSR2, LBR
CC       and PRM1. Phosphorylates SRSF1 using a directional (C-terminal to
CC       N-terminal) and a dual-track mechanism incorporating both
CC       processive phosphorylation (in which the kinase stays attached to
CC       the substrate after each round of phosphorylation) and
CC       distributive phosphorylation steps (in which the kinase and
CC       substrate dissociate after each phosphorylation event). The RS
CC       domain of SRSF1 binds first to a docking groove in the large lobe
CC       of the kinase domain of SRPK1. This induces certain structural
CC       changes in SRPK1 and/or RRM2 domain of SRSF1, allowing RRM2 to
CC       bind the kinase and initiate phosphorylation. The cycles continue
CC       for several phosphorylation steps in a processive manner (steps 1-
CC       8) until the last few phosphorylation steps (approximately steps
CC       9-12). During that time, a mechanical stress induces the unfolding
CC       of the beta-4 motif in RRM2, which then docks at the docking
CC       groove of SRPK1. This also signals RRM2 to begin to dissociate,
CC       which facilitates SRSF1 dissociation after phosphorylation is
CC       completed. Can mediate hepatitis B virus (HBV) core protein
CC       phosphorylation. It plays a negative role in the regulation of HBV
CC       replication through a mechanism not involving the phosphorylation
CC       of the core protein but by reducing the packaging efficiency of
CC       the pregenomic RNA (pgRNA) without affecting the formation of the
CC       viral core particles. Can induce splicing of exon 10 in MAPT/TAU
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10390541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9446799}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:10390541,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:9446799};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by phosphorylation on Ser-51 and Ser-
CC       548. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q96SB4}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. Found in a multisubunit complex containing seven
CC       proteins, named toposome, which separates entangled circular
CC       chromatin DNA during chromosome segregation. Interacts with HHV-1
CC       ICP27 protein. Interacts with DNAJB1/HSP40 and AHSA1/AHA1 and this
CC       mediates formation of a complex with the Hsp70 /Hsp90 machinery.
CC       Binds to IGF2BP1, SYNCRIP, HNRNPA2B1 and HNRNPC. Interacts with
CC       SAFB/SAFB1 and SAFB2 which inhibits its activity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q07955:SRSF1 (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-593343, EBI-398920;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus matrix {ECO:0000250}. Microsome
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Shuttles between the nucleus and the
CC       cytoplasm. Inhibition of the Hsp90 ATPase activity, osmotic stress
CC       and interaction with HHV-1 ICP27 protein can induce its
CC       translocation to the nucleus. KAT5/TIP60 inhibits its nuclear
CC       translocation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in the testis but is
CC       also present at lower levels in heart, spleen, liver, brain,
CC       kidney, lung and skeletal muscle. Present in all germinal cells in
CC       the seminiferous tubules but not in mature spermatozoa.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10390541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9446799}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. CMGC
CC       Ser/Thr protein kinase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 protein kinase domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00159}.

RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION OF THE NBAF AND NPBAF COMPLEXES, IDENTIFICATION BY MASS
RP   SPECTROMETRY, IDENTIFICATION IN THE NBAF AND NPBAF COMPLEXES, AND
RP   DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE.
RX   PubMed=17640523; DOI=10.1016/j.neuron.2007.06.019;
RA   Lessard J., Wu J.I., Ranish J.A., Wan M., Winslow M.M., Staahl B.T.,
RA   Wu H., Aebersold R., Graef I.A., Crabtree G.R.;
RT   "An essential switch in subunit composition of a chromatin remodeling
RT   complex during neural development.";
RL   Neuron 55:201-215(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Core component of the BAF (SWI/SNF) complex. This ATP-
CC       dependent chromatin-remodeling complex plays important roles in
CC       cell proliferation and differentiation, in cellular antiviral
CC       activities and inhibition of tumor formation. The BAF complex is
CC       able to create a stable, altered form of chromatin that constrains
CC       fewer negative supercoils than normal. This change in supercoiling
CC       would be due to the conversion of up to one-half of the
CC       nucleosomes on polynucleosomal arrays into asymmetric structures,
CC       termed altosomes, each composed of 2 histones octamers. Stimulates
CC       in vitro the remodeling activity of SMARCA4/BRG1/BAF190A. Plays a
CC       key role in cell-cycle control and causes cell cycle arrest in
CC       G0/G1. Belongs to the neural progenitors-specific chromatin
CC       remodeling complex (npBAF complex) and the neuron-specific
CC       chromatin remodeling complex (nBAF complex). During neural
CC       development a switch from a stem/progenitor to a post-mitotic
CC       chromatin remodeling mechanism occurs as neurons exit the cell
CC       cycle and become committed to their adult state. The transition
CC       from proliferating neural stem/progenitor cells to post-mitotic
CC       neurons requires a switch in subunit composition of the npBAF and
CC       nBAF complexes. As neural progenitors exit mitosis and
CC       differentiate into neurons, npBAF complexes which contain
CC       ACTL6A/BAF53A and PHF10/BAF45A, are exchanged for homologous
CC       alternative ACTL6B/BAF53B and DPF1/BAF45B or DPF3/BAF45C subunits
CC       in neuron-specific complexes (nBAF). The npBAF complex is
CC       essential for the self-renewal/proliferative capacity of the
CC       multipotent neural stem cells. The nBAF complex along with CREST
CC       plays a role regulating the activity of genes essential for
CC       dendrite growth. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17640523}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the BAF (hSWI/SNF) complex, which includes
CC       at least actin (ACTB), ARID1A, ARID1B/BAF250, SMARCA2,
CC       SMARCA4/BRG1/BAF190A, ACTL6A/BAF53, ACTL6B/BAF53B, SMARCE1/BAF57
CC       SMARCC1/BAF155, SMARCC2/BAF170, SMARCB1/SNF5/INI1, and one or more
CC       of SMARCD1/BAF60A, SMARCD2/BAF60B, or SMARCD3/BAF60C. In muscle
CC       cells, the BAF complex also contains DPF3. Interacts with MYK and
CC       MAEL. Interacts with PPP1R15A (By similarity). Component of neural
CC       progenitors-specific chromatin remodeling complex (npBAF complex)
CC       composed of at least, ARID1A/BAF250A or ARID1B/BAF250B,
CC       SMARCD1/BAF60A, SMARCD3/BAF60C, SMARCA2/BRM/BAF190B,
CC       SMARCA4/BRG1/BAF190A, SMARCB1/BAF47, SMARCC1/BAF155,
CC       SMARCE1/BAF57, SMARCC2/BAF170, PHF10/BAF45A, ACTL6A/BAF53A and
CC       actin. Component of neuron-specific chromatin remodeling complex
CC       (nBAF complex) composed of at least, ARID1A/BAF250A or
CC       ARID1B/BAF250B, SMARCD1/BAF60A, SMARCD3/BAF60C,
CC       SMARCA2/BRM/BAF190B, SMARCA4/BRG1/BAF190A, SMARCB1/BAF47,
CC       SMARCC1/BAF155, SMARCE1/BAF57, SMARCC2/BAF170, DPF1/BAF45B,
CC       DPF3/BAF45C, ACTL6B/BAF53B and actin. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16787967, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17640523}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P97496:Smarcc1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-689365, EBI-648047;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=A; Synonyms=INI1A;
CC         IsoId=Q9Z0H3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B; Synonyms=INI1B;
CC         IsoId=Q9Z0H3-2; Sequence=VSP_004400;
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed ubiquitously throughout the
CC       developing spinal cord, brain and other embryonic tissues at
CC       E10.5-E16.5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17640523}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNF5 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=FVB/N; TISSUE=Kidney;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Complexes with metalloproteinases (such as collagenases)
CC       and irreversibly inactivates them by binding to their catalytic
CC       zinc cofactor. May form part of a tissue-specific acute response
CC       to remodeling stimuli.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with EFEMP1. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, extracellular space, extracellular
CC       matrix.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highest levels are found in kidney, lung and
CC       brain followed by ovary and uterus. Low levels are found in bone.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Highly induced by phorbol ester (PMA), EGF and
CC       transforming growth factor-beta 1. Also induced by dexamethasone.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protease inhibitor I35 (TIMP) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 NTR domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00295}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Binds hyperacetylated chromatin and plays a role in the
CC       regulation of transcription, probably by chromatin remodeling.
CC       Regulates transcription of the CCND1 gene. Plays a role in
CC       nucleosome assembly (By similarity). May play a role in
CC       spermatogenesis or folliculogenesis. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9693039, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9811568}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with E2F1 and with histone H4
CC       acetylated at 'Lys-13' (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9693039,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9811568}. Note=Detected on chromatin and
CC       nucleosomes. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q7JJ13-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q7JJ13-2; Sequence=VSP_022601;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in the testis,
CC       followed by ovary, placenta, embryo and to a lower extent in
CC       somatic tissues. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9693039,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9811568}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: One bromodomain is sufficient for a partial interaction
CC       with histone H4 acetylated at 'Lys-13'. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 2 bromo domains. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00035}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 NET domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-

RP   INTERACTION WITH PAF49/CD3EAP.
RX   PubMed=15226435; DOI=10.1128/MCB.24.14.6338-6349.2004;
RA   Yamamoto K., Yamamoto M., Hanada K., Nogi Y., Matsuyama T.,
RA   Muramatsu M.;
RT   "Multiple protein-protein interactions by RNA polymerase I-associated
RT   factor PAF49 and role of PAF49 in rRNA transcription.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Biol. 24:6338-6349(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: DNA-dependent RNA polymerase catalyzes the transcription
CC       of DNA into RNA using the four ribonucleoside triphosphates as
CC       substrates. Component of RNA polymerase I which synthesizes
CC       ribosomal RNA precursors. Appears to be involved in the formation
CC       of the initiation complex at the promoter by mediating the
CC       interaction between Pol I and UBTF/UBF.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8641287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9254723}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the RNA polymerase I (Pol I) complex
CC       consisting of at least 13 subunits (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       PAF49/CD3EAP. Also binds UBTF/UBF. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15226435, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8641287,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9254723}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8641287, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9254723}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q8K202-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q8K202-2; Sequence=VSP_013536;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8K202-3; Sequence=VSP_013536, VSP_013537, VSP_013538;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic RPA49/POLR1E RNA polymerase
CC       subunit family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the transport of early endosomes at the
CC       level of transition between microfilament-based and microtubule-
CC       based movement (By similarity). May be involved in the
CC       cytoskeletal organization of neuronal growth cones. Seems to be
CC       inactive as a PPIase. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16756961}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with WIP and actin. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16756961}.
CC       Cell projection, axon {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16756961}. Early
CC       endosome {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16756961}. Note=Present in axons and
CC       neuronal growth cones.

CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in brain, with highest levels in the
CC       granular cell layer of cerebellum and in the granule cell layer of
CC       dentate gyrus. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16756961}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Strongly expressed in the developing nervous
CC       system at E18.5. Present in brain, heart, lung, kidney and thymus
CC       at E18.5 (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16756961}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PPIase FKBP-type domain seems to be inactive both for
CC       FK506-binding and enzymatic activity.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The central coiled-coil region is responsible for
CC       association with early endosomes. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FKBP-type PPIase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 PPIase FKBP-type domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00277}.

RP   GLYCYLATION.
RX   PubMed=19524510; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2009.05.020;
RA   Rogowski K., Juge F., van Dijk J., Wloga D., Strub J.-M.,
RA   Levilliers N., Thomas D., Bre M.-H., Van Dorsselaer A., Gaertig J.,
RA   Janke C.;
RT   "Evolutionary divergence of enzymatic mechanisms for posttranslational
RT   polyglycylation.";
RL   Cell 137:1076-1087(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Implicated in a number of cellular processes, including
CC       proliferation, differentiation, caspase-dependent and caspase-
CC       independent apoptosis, suppression of transformation (tumor
CC       suppressor), inhibition of protein phosphatase 2A, regulation of
CC       mRNA trafficking and stability in association with ELAVL1, and
CC       inhibition of acetyltransferases as part of the INHAT (inhibitor
CC       of histone acetyltransferases) complex. Plays a role in E4F1-
CC       mediated transcriptional repression.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17557114}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the SET complex, composed of at least
CC       ANP32A, APEX1, HMGB2, NME1, SET and TREX1. Directly interacts with
CC       SET. Interacts with ATXN1/SCA1. Interacts with MAP1B. Interacts
CC       with ELAVL1. Part of the INHAT (inhibitor of histone
CC       acetyltransferases) complex. Interacts with E4F1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12807913, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17557114,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9353121}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q8CCE9:E4f1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-643140, EBI-7450874;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12807913}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12807913}. Endoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Shuttles between nucleus and cytoplasm.
CC       Translocates to the cytoplasm during the process of
CC       neuritogenesis.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in the cerebellum.
CC       Expressed also in cortex, lung, skeletal muscle, gastrointestinal
CC       tract, spleen, liver and heart. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15895553}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on serine residues. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Some glutamate residues are glycylated by TTLL8. This
CC       modification occurs exclusively on glutamate residues and results
CC       in a glycine chain on the gamma-carboxyl group.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice are viable and fertile. They have no
CC       derangements in any of the major organ systems, including the
CC       nervous systems. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15060138}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ANP32 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 4 LRR (leucine-rich) repeats. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 LRRCT domain. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as component of the Arp2/3 complex which is
CC       involved in regulation of actin polymerization and together with
CC       an activating nucleation-promoting factor (NPF) mediates the
CC       formation of branched actin networks. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Arp2/3 complex composed of ARP2, ARP3,
CC       ARPC1B/p41-ARC, ARPC2/p34-ARC, ARPC3/p21-ARC, ARPC4/p20-ARC and
CC       ARPC5/p16-ARC. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton {ECO:0000250}. Cell
CC       projection {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Polyubiquitinated by RNF128 with 'Lys-63'-linked chains,
CC       leading to proteasomal degradation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ARPC5 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION IN ENDOCYTOSIS, AND INTERACTION WITH DNM1.
RX   PubMed=19781630; DOI=10.1016/j.cellsig.2009.09.022;
RA   Karim Z., Vepachedu R., Gorska M., Alam R.;
RT   "UNC119 inhibits dynamin and dynamin-dependent endocytic processes.";
RL   Cell. Signal. 22:128-137(2010).
RN   [7]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=21642972; DOI=10.1038/nn.2835;
RA   Zhang H., Constantine R., Vorobiev S., Chen Y., Seetharaman J.,
RA   Huang Y.J., Xiao R., Montelione G.T., Gerstner C.D., Davis M.W.,
RA   Inana G., Whitby F.G., Jorgensen E.M., Hill C.P., Tong L., Baehr W.;
RT   "UNC119 is required for G protein trafficking in sensory neurons.";
RL   Nat. Neurosci. 14:874-880(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in synaptic functions in photoreceptor cells,
CC       the signal transduction in immune cells as a Src family kinase
CC       activator, endosome recycling, the uptake of bacteria and
CC       endocytosis, protein trafficking in sensory neurons and as lipid-
CC       binding chaperone with specificity for a diverse subset of
CC       myristoylated proteins. Specifically binds the myristoyl moiety of
CC       a subset of N-terminally myristoylated proteins and is required
CC       for their localization. Binds myristoylated GNAT1 and is required
CC       for G-protein localization and trafficking in sensory neurons
CC       (PubMed:21642972). Probably plays a role in trafficking proteins
CC       in photoreceptor cells (PubMed:17174953). Plays important roles in
CC       mediating Src family kinase signals for the completion of
CC       cytokinesis via RAB11A. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13432,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17174953, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19781630,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21642972}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May interact with GTP-bound ARL1. Interacts with ARL2 and
CC       ARL3 (GTP-bound forms); this promotes the release of myristoylated
CC       cargo proteins (By similarity). Found in a complex with ARL3, RP2
CC       and UNC119; RP2 induces hydrolysis of GTP ARL3 in the complex,
CC       leading to the release of UNC119. Interacts with NPHP3 (when
CC       myristoylated). Interacts with CYS1 (when myristoylated).
CC       Interacts with C5orf30; interaction only takes place when UNC119
CC       is not liganded with myristoylated proteins (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with CABP4; in the absence of calcium. Interacts with
CC       DNM1; leading to a decrease of DNM1 GTPase activity. Interacts
CC       with LCK; this interaction plays a crucial role in activation of
CC       LCK (By similarity). Interacts with FYN (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with RAB11A; in a cell cycle-dependent manner (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with LYN (via SH2 and SH3 domains); leading to LYN
CC       activation (By similarity). Found in a complex with ABL1, ABL2,
CC       CRK and UNC119; leading to the inhibition of CRK phosphorylation
CC       by ABL kinases. Interacts with CD44 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, microtubule
CC       organizing center, centrosome {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13432}.
CC       Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, spindle {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13432}.
CC       Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, spindle pole
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13432}. Note=ocalizes to the centrosome in
CC       interphase cells and begins to translocate from the spindle pole
CC       to the spindle midzone after the onset of mitosis; it then
CC       localizes to the intercellular bridge in telophase cells and to
CC       the midbody in cytokinetic cells. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13432}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Localized in photoreceptor synapses in the
CC       outer plexiform layer of the retina.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18296658}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Adopts an immunoglobulin-like beta-sandwich fold forming a
CC       hydrophobic cavity that captures N-terminally myristoylated target
CC       peptides. Phe residues within the hydrophobic beta sandwich are
CC       required for myristate binding (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13432}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice develop a slowly progressive retinal
CC       degeneration, characterized by mottling in the fundus, mild
CC       thinning of the photoreceptor layer, and increase in apoptosis as
CC       early as 6 months, dramatic acceleration at approximately 17
CC       months, and virtual obliteration of the photoreceptors by 20
CC       months. Phenotypes are due to defects in protein trafficking, such
CC       as Gnat1 mislocalization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17174953,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21642972}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PDE6D/unc-119 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [24]
RP   FUNCTION IN DEACETYLATION OF HISTONE H4 AND ALPHA-TUBULIN, FUNCTION IN
RP   OOCYTE MEIOSIS, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=24334550; DOI=10.1096/fj.13-244111;
RA   Zhang L., Hou X., Ma R., Moley K., Schedl T., Wang Q.;
RT   "Sirt2 functions in spindle organization and chromosome alignment in
RT   mouse oocyte meiosis.";
RL   FASEB J. 28:1435-1445(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: NAD-dependent protein deacetylase, which deacetylates
CC       internal lysines on histone and alpha-tubulin as well as many
CC       other proteins such as key transcription factors. Participates in
CC       the modulation of multiple and diverse biological processes such
CC       as cell cycle control, genomic integrity, microtubule dynamics,
CC       cell differentiation, metabolic networks, and autophagy. Plays a
CC       major role in the control of cell cycle progression and genomic
CC       stability. Functions in the antephase checkpoint preventing
CC       precocious mitotic entry in response to microtubule stress agents,
CC       and hence allowing proper inheritance of chromosomes. Positively
CC       regulates the anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome (APC/C)
CC       ubiquitin ligase complex activity by deacetylating CDC20 and FZR1,
CC       then allowing progression through mitosis. Associates with both
CC       chromatin at transcriptional start sites (TSSs) and enhancers of
CC       active genes. Plays a role in cell cycle and chromatin compaction
CC       through epigenetic modulation of the regulation of histone H4
CC       'Lys-20' methylation (H4K20me1) during early mitosis. Specifically
CC       deacetylates histone H4 at 'Lys-16' (H4K16ac) between the G2/M
CC       transition and metaphase enabling H4K20me1 deposition by SETD8
CC       leading to ulterior levels of H4K20me2 and H4K20me3 deposition
CC       throughout cell cycle, and mitotic S-phase progression.
CC       Deacetylates SETD8 modulating SETD8 chromatin localization during
CC       the mitotic stress response. Deacetylates also histone H3 at 'Lys-
CC       57' (H3K56ac) during the mitotic G2/M transition. During oocyte
CC       meiosis progression, may deacetylate histone H4 at 'Lys-16'
CC       (H4K16ac) and alpha-tubulin, regulating spindle assembly and
CC       chromosome alignment by influencing microtubule dynamics and
CC       kinetochore function. Deacetylates alpha-tubulin at 'Lys-40' and
CC       hence controls neuronal motility, oligodendroglial cell arbor
CC       projection processes and proliferation of non-neuronal cells.
CC       Phosphorylation at Ser-368 by a G1/S-specific cyclin E-CDK2
CC       complex inactivates SIRT2-mediated alpha-tubulin deacetylation,
CC       negatively regulating cell adhesion, cell migration and neurite
CC       outgrowth during neuronal differentiation. Deacetylates PARD3 and
CC       participates in the regulation of Schwann cell peripheral
CC       myelination formation during early postnatal development and
CC       during postinjury remyelination. Involved in several cellular
CC       metabolic pathways. Plays a role in the regulation of blood
CC       glucose homeostasis by deacetylating and stabilizing
CC       phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase PCK1 activity in response to low
CC       nutrient availability. Acts as a key regulator in the pentose
CC       phosphate pathway (PPP) by deacetylating and activating the
CC       glucose-6-phosphate G6PD enzyme, and therefore, stimulates the
CC       production of cytosolic NADPH to counteract oxidative damage.
CC       Maintains energy homeostasis in response to nutrient deprivation
CC       as well as energy expenditure by inhibiting adipogenesis and
CC       promoting lipolysis. Attenuates adipocyte differentiation by
CC       deacetylating and promoting FOXO1 interaction to PPARG and
CC       subsequent repression of PPARG-dependent transcriptional activity.
CC       Plays a role in the regulation of lysosome-mediated degradation of
CC       protein aggregates by autophagy in neuronal cells. Deacetylates
CC       FOXO1 in response to oxidative stress or serum deprivation,
CC       thereby negatively regulating FOXO1-mediated autophagy.
CC       Deacetylates a broad range of transcription factors and co-
CC       regulators regulating target gene expression. Deacetylates
CC       transcriptional factor FOXO3 stimulating the ubiquitin ligase
CC       SCF(SKP2)-mediated FOXO3 ubiquitination and degradation.
CC       Deacetylates HIF1A, and therefore promotes HIF1A degradation and
CC       inhibition of HIF1A transcriptional activity in tumor cells in
CC       response to hypoxia. Deacetylates RELA in the cytoplasm inhibiting
CC       NF-kappaB-dependent transcription activation upon TNF-alpha
CC       stimulation. Inhibits transcriptional activation by deacetylating
CC       p53/TP53 and EP300. Deacetylates also EIF5A. Functions as a
CC       negative regulator on oxidative stress-tolerance in response to
CC       anoxia-reoxygenation conditions. Plays a role as tumor suppressor.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform 1: Deacetylates alpha-tubulin.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform 2: Deacetylates alpha-tubulin.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform 4: Deacetylates alpha-tubulin.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: NAD(+) + an acetylprotein = nicotinamide + O-
CC       acetyl-ADP-ribose + a protein. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00236}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Sirtinol, A3 and M15 small
CC       molecules. Inhibited by nicotinamide. Inhibited by a macrocyclic
CC       peptide inhibitor S2iL5. Inhibited by EP300-induced acetylation
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer. Interacts (via both phosphorylated,
CC       unphosphorylated, active or inactive forms) with HDAC6; the
CC       interaction is necessary for the complex to interact with alpha-
CC       tubulin, suggesting that these proteins belong to a large complex
CC       that deacetylates the cytoskeleton. Interacts with RELA; the
CC       interaction occurs in the cytoplasm and is increased in a TNF-
CC       alpha-dependent manner. Interacts with HOXA10; the interaction is
CC       direct. Interacts with YWHAB and YWHAG; the interactions occur in
CC       a AKT-dependent manner and increase SIRT2-dependent TP53
CC       deacetylation. Interacts with MAPK1/ERK2 and MAPK3/ERK1; the
CC       interactions increase SIRT2 stability and deacetylation activity.
CC       Interacts (phosphorylated form) with SETD8; the interaction is
CC       direct, stimulates SETD8-mediated methyltransferase activity on
CC       histone at 'Lys-20' (H4K20me1) and is increased in a H(2)O(2)-
CC       induced oxidative stress-dependent manner. Interacts with G6PD;
CC       the interaction is enhanced by H(2)O(2) treatment. Interacts (via
CC       C-terminus region) with EP300. Interacts with HIF1A. Interacts
CC       with a G1/S-specific cyclin E-CDK2 complex (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with FOXO1; the interaction is disrupted upon serum-
CC       starvation or oxidative stress, leading to increased level of
CC       acetylated FOXO1 and induction of autophagy. Interacts with AURKA,
CC       CDC20, CDK5 (p35 form), FOXO3 and FZR1. Isoform 2 and isoform 4
CC       associate with microtubule in primary cortical mature neurons.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17521387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17681146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18332217,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19037106, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22014574}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       O14965:AURKA (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-911012, EBI-448680;
CC       Q9JJ66:Cdc20; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-911012, EBI-2551389;
CC       Q9R1K5:Fzr1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-911012, EBI-5238560;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Cytoplasm. Cytoplasm, perinuclear
CC       region. Perikaryon. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton. Cell projection. Cell
CC       projection, growth cone. Myelin membrane. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton,
CC       microtubule organizing center, centrosome. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton, spindle. Chromosome. Midbody. Cytoplasm,
CC       cytoskeleton, microtubule organizing center, centrosome, centriole
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=Localizes in the cytoplasm during most of the
CC       cell cycle except in the G2/M transition and during mitosis, where
CC       it is localized in association with chromatin and induces
CC       deacetylation of histone at 'Lys-16' (H4K16ac). Colocalizes with
CC       CDK1 at centrosome during prophase and splindle fibers during
CC       metaphase. Colocalizes with Aurora kinase AURKA in centrioles
CC       during early prophase and growing mitotic spindle throughout
CC       metaphase. Colocalizes with Aurora kinase AURKB during cytokinesis
CC       with the midbody. Detected in perinuclear foci that may be
CC       aggresomes containing misfolded, ubiquitinated proteins. Shuttles
CC       between the cytoplasm and the nucleus through the CRM1 export
CC       pathway. Colocalizes with EP300 in the nucleus. Colocalizes with
CC       PARD3 in internodal region of axons. Colocalizes with acetylated
CC       alpha-tubulin in cell projection processes during primary
CC       oligodendrocyte precursor (OLP) differentiation (By similarity).
CC       Deacetylates FOXO3 in the cytoplasm. Colocalizes with Aurora
CC       kinase AURKA at centrosome. Colocalizes with microtubules.
CC       Colocalizes with PLP1 in internodal regions of myelin sheat, at
CC       paranodal axoglial junction and Schmidt-Lanterman incisures.
CC       Colocalizes with CDK5R1 in the perikaryon, neurites and growth
CC       cone of hippocampal neurons. Colocalizes with alpha-tubulin in
CC       neuronal growth cone. Colocalizes with SETD8 at mitotic foci.
CC       Localizes in the cytoplasm and nucleus of germinal vesicle (GV)
CC       stage oocytes. Colocalizes with alpha-tubulin on the meiotic
CC       spindle as the oocytes enter into metaphase, and also during
CC       meiotic anaphase and telophase, especially with the midbody.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=SIRT2.1;
CC         IsoId=Q8VDQ8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=SIRT2.2;
CC         IsoId=Q8VDQ8-2; Sequence=VSP_008729;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q8VDQ8-3; Sequence=VSP_055330;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=SIRT2.3;
CC         IsoId=Q8VDQ8-4; Sequence=VSP_055329;
CC         Note=Gene prediction based on EST data.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform 1 is weakly expressed in the cortex at
CC       postnatal(P) days P1, P3 and P7, and increases progressively
CC       between P17 and older adult cortex. Isoform 1 is also expressed in
CC       heart, liver and skeletal muscle, weakly expressed in the striatum
CC       and spinal cord. Isoform 2 is not expressed in the cortex at P1,
CC       P3 and P7, and increases strongly and progressively between P17
CC       and older adult cortex. Isoform 2 is also expressed in the heart,
CC       liver, striatum and spinal cord. Isoform 4 is weakly expressed in
CC       older adult cortex and spinal cords. Expressed in the cortex.
CC       Expressed in postnatal sciatic nerves during myelination and
CC       during remyelination after nerve injury. Expressed in neurons,
CC       oligodendrocytes, Schwann cells, Purkinje cells and in astrocytes
CC       of white matter. Strongly expressed in preadipocytes compared with
CC       differentiated adipocytes. Expressed in cerebellar granule cells.
CC       Expressed in the inner ear: in the cochlea, expressed in types I
CC       and V fibrocytes in the spiral ligament (SL) and slightly in stria
CC       vascularis (SV); in the organ of Corti, expressed in some
CC       supporting cells; in the crista ampullaris, expressed in spiral
CC       ganglion cells; also expressed in the endolymphatic sac (ES)
CC       epithelial cells (at protein level). Expressed in the brain,
CC       spinal cord, optic nerve and hippocampus. Strongly expressed in 6-
CC       8 week-old ovulated meiosis II oocytes and weakly expressed in 45-
CC       58 week-old ovulated meiosis II oocytes. Expressed in the cochlea,
CC       vestibule and acoustic nerve of the inner ear.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16933150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17634366,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17681146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18332217,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21791548, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21949390,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24334550, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24460154}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Isoform 1 is expressed in the cortex at 15.5
CC       dpc. Isoform 2 is not detected in the cortex at 15.5 dpc (at
CC       protein level).
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated in response to caloric restriction in
CC       white and brown adipose tissues. Up-regulated during cold exposure
CC       and down-regulated in higher ambient temperature in brown adipose
CC       tissue. Up-regulated after beta-adrenergic agonist (isoproterenol)
CC       treatment in white adipose tissue (at protein level). Up-regulated
CC       in response to caloric restriction in adipose tissue and kidney.
CC       Up-regulated in response to oxidative stress. Up-regulated during
CC       postnatal sciatic nerve myelination development and axonal
CC       regeneration. Down-regulated during preadipocyte differentiation.
CC       Down-regulated in Schwann dedifferentiated cells during Wallerian
CC       degeneration. Isoform 1 is up-regulated upon differentiation to a
CC       neuron-like phenotype. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17521387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17681146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19037106,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21791548, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21949390}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated at phosphoserine and phosphothreonine.
CC       Phosphorylated at Ser-368 by a mitotic kinase CDK1/cyclin B at the
CC       G2/M transition; phosphorylation regulates the delay in cell-cycle
CC       progression. Phosphorylated at Ser-368 by a mitotic kinase G1/S-
CC       specific cyclin E/Cdk2 complex; phosphorylation inactivates SIRT2-
CC       mediated alpha-tubulin deacetylation and thereby negatively
CC       regulates cell adhesion, cell migration and neurite outgrowth
CC       during neuronal differentiation. Phosphorylated by cyclin A/Cdk2
CC       and p35-Cdk5 complexes and to a lesser extent by the cyclin
CC       D3/Cdk4 and cyclin B/Cdk1, in vitro. Dephosphorylated at Ser-368
CC       by CDC14A and CDC14B around early anaphase (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Acetylated by EP300; acetylation leads both to the decreased
CC       of SIRT2-mediated alpha-tubulin deacetylase activity and SIRT2-
CC       mediated down-regulation of TP53 transcriptional activity.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Tissue-specific knockout of SIRT2 in Schwann
CC       cells of early postnatal mice leads to a transient delay in
CC       myelination, a reduction in the nerve conduction velocity and
CC       hyperacetylation of PARD3. The number of dividing Schwann cells in
CC       the developing nerve and alpha-tubulin acetylation are normal
CC       (PubMed:21949390). Mutant mice embryo grow normally and new born
CC       are healthy. Embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) display reduced cell
CC       proliferation capacity, centrosome amplification and mitotic cell
CC       death. Nude mice inoculated with immortalized MEFs from mutant
CC       mice developed tumors. Adult mutant mice exhibit genomic
CC       instability and chromosomal aberrations, such as double-strand
CC       breaks (DSBs), with a gender-specific spectrum of tumorigenesis;
CC       females develop primarily mammary tumors and males develop tumors
CC       in several organs, including the liver, lung, pancreas, stomach,
CC       duodenum and prostate. Drastic increases of histone H4K16
CC       acetylation and decreases of both histone methylation (H4K20me1)
CC       in metaphasic chromosomes and histone methylations (H4K20me2/3) in
CC       late M/early G1 but also throughout all phases of the cell cycle
CC       (PubMed:23468428). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21949390,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22014574, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23468428}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the sirtuin family. Class I subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 deacetylase sirtuin-type domain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00236}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Electron carrier protein. The oxidized form of the
CC       cytochrome c heme group can accept an electron from the heme group
CC       of the cytochrome c1 subunit of cytochrome reductase. Cytochrome c
CC       then transfers this electron to the cytochrome oxidase complex,
CC       the final protein carrier in the mitochondrial electron-transport
CC       chain. {ECO:0000256|RuleBase:RU004427}.
CC   -!- PTM: Binds 1 heme group per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000256|RuleBase:RU004427}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome c family.
CC       {ECO:0000256|RuleBase:RU004426}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transcriptional regulator that plays a central role in
CC       Notch signaling, a signaling pathway involved in cell-cell
CC       communication that regulates a broad spectrum of cell-fate
CC       determinations. Acts as a transcriptional repressor when it is not
CC       associated with Notch proteins. When associated with some NICD
CC       product of Notch proteins (Notch intracellular domain), it acts as
CC       a transcriptional activator that activates transcription of Notch
CC       target genes. Probably represses or activates transcription via
CC       the recruitment of chromatin remodeling complexes containing
CC       histone deacetylase or histone acetylase proteins, respectively.
CC       Specifically binds to the immunoglobulin kappa-type J segment
CC       recombination signal sequence. Binds specifically to methylated
CC       DNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7566092}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RITA1, leading to nuclear export, prevent
CC       the interaction between RBPJ and NICD product and subsequent down-
CC       regulation of the Notch signaling pathway (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with activated NOTCH1, NOTCH2 and NOTCH3. Interacts with
CC       MINT/SHARP. This interaction may mediate the recruitment of large
CC       corepressor complexes containing proteins such as HDAC1, HDAC2,
CC       NCOR2, SAP30, FHL1/KYOT2 and CIR1. Interacts with EP300, MAML1 and
CC       PTF1A. Interacts with SNW1. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10640276, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11318877,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11604511, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7566092,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9418910}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q01705:Notch1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-1392666, EBI-1392707;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Note=Mainly nuclear, upon interaction with RITA1, translocates to
CC       the cytoplasm, down-regulating the Notch signaling pathway.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P31266-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P31266-2; Sequence=VSP_008392, VSP_008393;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Su(H) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 IPT/TIG domain. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Despite some similarity with the "phage" integrase
CC       family, it has no recombinase activity. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Inhibitor of cathepsin G, kallikrein-8 and thrombin. May
CC       play an important role in the inner ear in the protection against
CC       leakage of lysosomal content during stress. May be involved in the
CC       regulation of serine proteinases present in the brain or
CC       extravasated from the blood. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17761692}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with the monomeric form of beta-tryptase.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17761692,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20451170}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the inner ear hair cells,
CC       keratinocytes of hair follicles and epidermis in abdominal skin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17761692, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20451170}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: At E13.5, weakly detected in utricle sensory
CC       epithelium but not in hair cells. At E16.5, more prominently
CC       detected in crista hair cells. Hair cell expression is sustained
CC       in postnatal mice. In cochlea, detected in cochlear hair cells in
CC       embryo and in hair cells and the greater epithelial ridge (GER)
CC       region in early postnatal age. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20451170}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the serpin family. Ov-serpin subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RC   TISSUE=Embryonic fibroblast;

RA   Park J., Chen Y., Tishkoff D.X., Peng C., Tan M., Dai L., Xie Z.,
RA   Zhang Y., Zwaans B.M., Skinner M.E., Lombard D.B., Zhao Y.;
RT   "SIRT5-mediated lysine desuccinylation impacts diverse metabolic
RT   pathways.";
RL   Mol. Cell 50:919-930(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: T1-TrpRS has aminoacylation activity while T2-TrpRS
CC       lacks it. T1-TrpRS and T2-TrpRS possess angiostatic activity. T2-
CC       TrpRS inhibits fluid shear stress-activated responses of
CC       endothelial cells. Regulates ERK, Akt, and eNOS activation
CC       pathways that are associated with angiogenesis, cytoskeletal
CC       reorganization and shear stress-responsive gene expression (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + L-tryptophan + tRNA(Trp) = AMP +
CC       diphosphate + L-tryptophyl-tRNA(Trp).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with oxidized form of GAPDH (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=Long;
CC         IsoId=P32921-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Short;
CC         IsoId=P32921-2; Sequence=VSP_006313;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform 2 is widely expressed, isoform 1 is
CC       found only in embryonic stem cells.
CC   -!- PTM: Proteolytic cleavage generates 2 forms; T1-TrpRS and T2-
CC       TrpRS. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class-I aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 WHEP-TRS domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00531}.
